facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 65 of 1956 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeal No. 65 of 1956.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 22, 1955 of Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 22, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal

facts.text: Bombay High Court judgment in Criminal Revision Application No. 449 of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 22, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 449 of 1955,

facts.text: Arising out of judgment dated March 24, 1955 of Presidency Magistrate, Seventh Court, Dadar, Bombay in Case No. 215/S of 1955.

anchor.surface_text: arising out of the judgment and order dated March 24, 1955, of the Court of the Presidency Magistrate, Seventh Court, Dadar, Bombay in Case No. 215/S of 1955.

facts.text: Appellant is owner by purchase in 1945 of premises in Vile Parle, Bombay.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is the owner, by purchase in 1945, of certain premises situate in Vile Parle, Bombay.

facts.text: Thirumal Rao Potdar was tenant under predecessor-in-title at monthly rent Rs. 20 including Rs. 2 water rate.

anchor.surface_text: Under the predecessor-in- title of the appellant, was a tenant, named Thirumal Rao Potdar, in respect of a room in those premises, at a monthly rent of Rs. 20 including water rate of Rs. 2.

facts.text: After appellant's purchase, tenant continued on same terms.

anchor.surface_text: After the, appellaiits purchase, the tenant aforesaid companytinued to hold the tenancy on those very terms.

facts.text: Premises enjoyed water supply from municipal tap.

anchor.surface_text: The said premises used to enjoy the amenity of water supply from a municipal tap.

facts.text: Water supply cut off by Municipality early in May 1947 due to predecessor's default in municipal taxes.

anchor.surface_text: As the appellants predecessor-in -title had made default in payment of municipal taxes, the water supply had been cut off by the Municipality early in May, 1947.

facts.text: Tenants including Thirumal Rao used well water from neighbouring tenant after cut off.

anchor.surface_text: Since after that, the tenants including the said Thirumal Rao, had the use of well water only from a neigh- bouring tenant.

facts.text: Thirumal Rao died in or about 1950.

anchor.surface_text: Thirumal Rao died in or about the year 1950,

facts.text: Widow, first respondent, continued in occupation, paying original rent plus annas 10 permitted increase, without municipal water.

anchor.surface_text: and his widow, the first respondent, companytinued in occupation of the premises, without having the use of municipal water supply though she companytinued to pay the original rent plus annas 10 more by way of permitted increase.

facts.text: Appellant received Rs. 20-10-0 monthly rent from first respondent without providing municipal water.

anchor.surface_text: Thus, the landlord the appellant-went on receiving the monthly rent of Rs. 20-10-0 from the first respondent without giving her the benefit of water supply from the municipal tap.

facts.text: Bombay Rents Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act came into force on February 13, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: The Act came into force on February 13, 1948.

facts.text: Tenancy recorded in first respondent's name some time in 1951.

anchor.surface_text: The tenancy appears to have been recorded in her name some time in 1951.

facts.text: First respondent complained to Municipal authorities in April 1954 about water supply stopped since 1947.

anchor.surface_text: Nothing appears to have happened until April, 1954, when the first respondent brought it to the numberice of the Municipal authorities that the supply of water from the municipal tap had been stopped since 1947.

facts.text: Municipality letter dated May 24, 1954: water connection to be restored on payment of Rs. 11-4-0 if owner's consent produced.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipality answered the first respondents companyplaint by a letter dated May 24, 1954, saying that the water companynection companyld be restored on payment of Rs. 11-4-0 only, being the fee for doing so, if the owners companysent was produced.

facts.text: Tenant sent letter via pleader to appellant before Municipality reply, demanding refund Rs. 72 for 3 years water charge and restoration.

anchor.surface_text: Before receiving this answer from the Municipality, the tenant got a letter written to the appellant, through a pleader, asking him to refund Rs. 72 being the amount charged for water supply at Rs. 2 per month, which was included in the total rent aforesaid for three years after the tenancy had been mutated in her name.

facts.text: Letter stated water withheld by landlord allowing disconnection for non-payment of dues, threatened s.24 prosecution.

anchor.surface_text: The letter also stated that the supply of water had been withheld by the landlord by allowing the Municipality to disconnect the water companynection for number-payment of municipal dues. The landlord was also called upon to get the water companynection restored, and if he failed to do so, prosecution under 1397 s.24 of the Act, was threatened.

facts.text: First respondent filed complaint on June 14, 1954 for prosecution under s.24.

anchor.surface_text: As the appellant had refused or neglected to have the water companynection restored, the tenant filed a petition of companyplaint on June 14, 1954, for the prosecution of the appellant under s. 24 of the Act.

facts.text: Appellant convicted by 7th Presidency Magistrate on March 24, 1955: 1 day SI and Rs.150 fine or 1 month SI default.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was companyvicted. after a trial by the 7th Presidency Magistrate, Dadar, by his judgment and order dated March 24, 1955. He was sentenced to undergo one days simple imprisonment, and to pay a fine of Rs. 150, and in default of payment, to undergo one months simple imprison- ment.

facts.text: High Court rejected revision on April 22, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved the High Court of Bombay in revision against the order of companyviction and sentence aforesaid. The matter was heard by a judge sitting singly, who summarily rejected the application by an order dated April 22, 1955.

facts.text: Division Bench refused certificate on May 16, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant moved the High Court for a certificate that this was a fit case for appeal to this Court, which was refused by a Division Bench on May 16, 1955.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave on October 10, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, the appellant moved this Court for special leave which was granted on October 10, 1955.

facts.text: Explanation II to s.24 inserted by Bombay Act 61 of 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The explanation II was inserted by s. 16  2  of the Amending Act, namely, Bombay Act 61 of 1953,

facts.text: Supply of tap water is essential supply per Explanation I.

anchor.surface_text: It has number been denied before us that the supply of tap water is an essential supply, and that is beyond companytroversy in view of explanation 1.

facts.text: Municipality would restore water on payment of Rs.11-4-0 with owner's consent.

anchor.surface_text: The Municipality answered the first respondents companyplaint by a letter dated May 24, 1954, saying that the water companynection companyld be restored on payment of Rs. 11-4-0 only, being the fee for doing so, if the owners companysent was produced.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on February 20, 1958 by SINHA J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. February 20. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by SINHA J.-
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 22, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Criminal Revision Application No. 449 of 1955,
Thereafter, the appellant moved this Court for special leave which was granted on October 10, 1955.

s. 24 1  4  of the Bombay Rents Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act LVII of 1947  hereinafter referred to as the Act , has been brought home to the appellant. The facts of this case are short and simple. The appellant is the owner, by purchase in 1945,

concepts.interpretation: No landlord shall without just or sufficient cause cut off or withhold any essential supply or service enjoyed by the tenant. Requires enjoyment of supply after Act's commencement and omission attributable to landlord per Expl II.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: if he failed to do so, prosecution under 1397 s.24 of the Act, was threatened. As the appellant had refused or neglected to have the water companynect

concepts.unlisted_label: Section 24 Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947
concepts.unlisted_description: Prohibits landlord from cutting off essential supplies enjoyed by tenant without cause; provides remedies and penalties.

anchor.surface_text: Explanation I.-In this section essential supply or service includes supply of water, electricity, lights in passages and on staircases, lifts and conservancy or sanitary service.

concepts.interpretation: Supply of tap water is an essential supply.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: months or with fine or with both. Explanation I.-In this section essential supply or service includ

concepts.unlisted_label: Explanation I to Section 24 Bombay Rents Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Defines essential supply or service to include water supply.

anchor.surface_text: The explanation II was inserted by s. 16  2  of the Amending Act, namely, Bombay Act 61 of 1953,

concepts.interpretation: Withholding includes acts or omissions attributable to landlord causing cut off by local authority. Omission to pay Rs.11-4-0 to restore is attributable.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: months or with fine or with both. Explanation I.-In this section essential supply or service includes supply of water, electricity, lights in passages

concepts.unlisted_label: Explanation II to Section 24 Bombay Rents Act
concepts.unlisted_description: Withholding essential supply includes landlord's acts/omissions leading to cut off by local authority.

anchor.surface_text: The explanation II was inserted by s. 16  2  of the Amending Act, namely, Bombay Act 61 of 1953,

concepts.unlisted_description: Amending provision inserting Expl II to s.24 of 1947 Act.

concepts.interpretation: Prohibits retrospective criminal liability; enjoyment must be post-Act to avoid ex post facto effect.

concepts.unlisted_description: Protection against ex post facto criminal laws.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, the provisions of s. 24 have to be construed as a whole, in order to find out the true intention of the Legislature.

concepts.interpretation: Section 24 subsections read together; 'enjoyed' informed by sub-s.(3) implying recent enjoyment.

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ved the High Court of Bombay in revision against the order of companyviction and sentence aforesaid. The matter was heard by a judge sitting singly, w

anchor.surface_text: Such remedies which are inroads upon the landlords freedom of action, have to be construed strictly in accordance with the words actually used by the Legislature, and they cannot be given an extended meaning.

concepts.interpretation: Penal provisions like s.24 strictly construed; 'enjoyed' not extended to mere right or remote past use.

concepts.unlisted_description: Penal laws construed strictly, no extension beyond words used.

issues.text: The only question for determination in this appeal, is whether an offence punishable under s. 24(4) of the Bombay Rents Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act LVII of 1947, hereinafter referred to as the Act, has been brought home to the appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The only question for determination in this appeal, is whether an offence punishable under s. 24 1  4  of the Bombay Rents Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act LVII of 1947  hereinafter referred to as the Act , has been b

issues.text: The most important question which we have to determine in this appeal, is whether the constituent elements of an offence under s. 24(1), have been made out on the facts found in this case.

anchor.surface_text: The most important question which we have to determine in this appeal, is whether the constituent elements of an offence under s. 24 1 , have been made out on the facts found in this case.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: months or with fine or with both. Explanation I.-In this section essential supply or service includes supply of water, electricity, lights in passages

arguments.court_reasoning: Withholding yes under Expl II but no prior enjoyment after Act

holdings.text: the supply of tap water is an essential supply, and that is beyond controversy in view of explanation I.

anchor.surface_text: It has not been denied before us that the supply of tap water is an essential supply, and that is beyond controversy in view of explanation 1.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed and directly follows from statutory definition in Explanation I.

holdings.text: in so far as the appellant omitted to do so, such an omission is attributable to him within the meaning of explanation II which was inserted into the Act in 1953. There can, therefore, be no doubt that the appellant was continuing to withhold an essential supply within the meaning of s. 24, as it stood in 1953.

anchor.surface_text: It may be that the appellant was not to blame for the default in payment of municipal dues, but it was open to him to pay Rs. 11-4-0 and have the water connection restored. He may not have been directly responsible for the .cutting off of the supply of municipal water, but it was within his power to get the supply restored by the Municipality on payment of the prescribed fee. Hence, in so far as the appellant omitted to do so, such an omission is attributable to him within the meaning of explanation II which was inserted into the Act in 1953. There can, therefore, be no doubt that the appellant was continuing to withhold an essenti

holdings.reasoning_summary: Landlord had power to restore supply by paying nominal fee of Rs. 11-4-0; omission falls within 'acts or omissions attributable to the landlord' per Explanation II.

holdings.text: the section makes it essential that the particular essential supply should have been available for the use of the tenant at some time when the Act was in force.

anchor.surface_text: In order to attract the provisions of that section, it is also necessary that the second ingredient of the offence, should be there, namely, that that essential supply-tap water supply by the Municipality- should have been enjoyed by the tenant. Is it enough that this essential supply should have been enjoyed by the tenant at any past time, however remote, or that it should have been enjoyed at any time after the coming into effect of the Act? [...] In our opinion, the section makes it essential that the particular essential supply should -have been available for the use of the tenant at some time when the Act was in force.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Requires availability post-commencement of Act to avoid ex post facto operation prohibited by Art. 20(1) Constitution.

holdings.text: it would be straining the language of the section to say that enjoyed should mean had the right to enjoy. That this was not the intention of the Legislature, becomes clear on an examination of the terms of sub.s. (3) of that section. It speaks of the tenant has been in enjoyment of the essential supply or service and that it was cut off or withheld by the landlord which imports recent enjoyment until the supply was cut off, and not enjoyment in the remote past.

anchor.surface_text: But it has been said that the expression enjoyed by the tenant in s. 24, does not necessarily mean that the tenant should have physically made use of the essential supply, and that the requirements of the section are satisfied if the tenant had the right vested in him to call for such a supply. [...] In our opinion, it would be straining the language of the section to say that enjoyed should mean had the right to enjoy . If that was the intention of the Legislature, those words would have been different. That this was not the intention of the Legislature, becomes clear on an examination of the terms of sub.s. (3) of that section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual meaning requires physical/recent use, confirmed by context of s.24(3); mere vested right insufficient.

holdings.text: the provisions of s. 24 have to be construed as a whole, in order to find out the true intention of the Legislature.

anchor.surface_text: But it was suggested that sub-s. (1) of s. 24, was self-contained, and that it was not necessary to construe its terms in the light of the provisions of sub-ss.(2) and (3) which go together. But it is clear from the terms of sub-s. (2) that it cannot come into operation without the landlord having contravened the provisions of sub-s. (1). Therefore, the provisions of s. 24 have to be construed as a whole, in order to find out the true intention of the Legislature.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Subsections interlinked; sub-s.(2) presupposes contravention of sub-s.(1).

holdings.text: Such remedies which are inroads upon the landlords freedom of action, have to be construed strictly in accordance with the words actually used by the Legislature, and they cannot be given an extended meaning.

anchor.surface_text: These are provisions of an exceptional character, meant to be in force for a specified period during which the Legislature thought it advisable and expedient to provide for such extraordinary remedies. Such remedies which are inroads upon the landlords freedom of action, have to be construed strictly in accordance with the words actually used by the Legislature, and they cannot be given an extended meaning.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.24 creates penal liabilities and extraordinary tenant remedies restricting landlord rights; strict interpretation required.

holdings.text: it is doubtful whether, before the second explanation was inserted into the section, as aforesaid, in 1953, the cutting off of the water supply by the Municipality, or the omission of the landlord to take steps to have the connection restored, would have come within the mischief of the penal section.

anchor.surface_text: It, may also be pointed out that it is doubtful whether, before the second explanation was inserted into the section, as aforesaid, in 1953, the cutting off of the water supply by the Municipality, or the omission of the landlord to take steps to have the connection restored, would have come within the mischief of the penal section.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-amendment, local authority cut-off not clearly attributable to landlord without Explanation II.

justification_sets.label: Section 24 Bombay Rents, Hotel and Lodging House Rates Control Act, 1947 support

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the section makes it essential that the particular essential supply should -have been available for the use of the tenant at some time when the Act was in force. If, on the other hand, the section were construed in the sense that the supply should have been enjoyed at some time in the remote past, that is, before the Act was enforced, the act of the landlord, when it was committed, may not have been penal but the same act would become penal on the coming into effect of the Act.

outcome.relief_summary: Offence under s.24 not established as essential supply not enjoyed by tenant after Act came into force

anchor.surface_text: sanitary service. Explanation II.-For the purposes of this section, withholding any essential supply or service shall include acts or omissions attrib

edges.explanation: h2 directly holds omission attributable under explanation II, answering i3

anchor.surface_text: It may be that the appellant was not to blame for the default in payment of municipal dues, but it was open to him to pay Rs. 11-4-0 and have the water connection restored. He may not have been directly responsible for the .cutting off of the supply of municipal water, but it was within his power to get the supply restored by the Municipality on payment of the prescribed fee. Hence, in so far as the appellant omitted to do so, such an omission is attributable to him within the meaning of explanation II which was inserted into the Act in 1953. There can, therefore, be no doubt that the appellant was continuing to withhold an essenti

In our opinion, the section makes it essential that the particular essential supply should -have been available for the use of the tenant at some time when the Act was in force. If, on the other hand, the section were construed in the sense that the supply should have been enjoyed at some time in the remote past, that is, before the Act was enforced, the act of the landlord, when it was committed, may not have been penal but the same act would become penal on the coming into effect of the Act.
e explanation 1, as it number stands, was the only explanation before the amending Act was passed. It has number been denied before us that the supply

edges.explanation: h3 holds supply must be available when Act in force, answering i4 on past vs after Act

anchor.surface_text: In order to attract the provisions of that section, it is also necessary that the second ingredient of the offence, should be there, namely, that that essential supply-tap water supply by the Municipality- should have been enjoyed by the tenant. Is it enough that this essential supply should have been enjoyed by the tenant at any past time, however remote, or that it should have been enjoyed at any time after the coming into effect of the Act? [...] In our opinion, the section makes it essential that the particular essential supply should -have been available for the use of the tenant at some time when the Act was in force.

In our opinion, the section makes it essential that the particular essential supply should -have been available for the use of the tenant at some time when the Act was in force. If, on the other hand, the section were construed in the sense that the supply should have been enjoyed at some time in the remote past, that is, before the Act was enforced, the act of the landlord, when it was committed, may not have been penal but the same act would become penal on the coming into effect of the Act.
s, by the appellants predecessor-in-title. It may be that the appellant was number to blame for the default in payment of municipal dues, but it was o

edges.explanation: h4 holds 'enjoyed' not mere right but strains language imply physical, answering i5

anchor.surface_text: But it has been said that the expression enjoyed by the tenant in s. 24, does not necessarily mean that the tenant should have physically made use of the essential supply, and that the requirements of the section are satisfied if the tenant had the right vested in him to call for such a supply. [...] In our opinion, it would be straining the language of the section to say that enjoyed should mean had the right to enjoy . If that was the intention of the Legislature, those words would have been different. That this was not the intention of the Legislature, becomes clear on an examination of the terms of sub.s. (3) of that section.

In our opinion, the section makes it essential that the particular essential supply should -have been available for the use of the tenant at some time when the Act was in force. If, on the other hand, the section were construed in the sense that the supply should have been enjoyed at some time in the remote past, that is, before the Act was enforced, the act of the landlord, when it was committed, may not have been penal but the same act would become penal on the coming into effect of the Act.
